qas.question: What is the stated objective of most intellectual property law?
What do patents create an incentive for inventors to do?
Which view treats intellectual property as another type of "real" property?
Which recent law stresses international harmonization?
What has the stated objective of protecting the inventor?
Who do patents keep from disclosing their work?

plausible_answers.text: This absolute protection or full value view

qas.question: What new treats intellectual property different than real property?
What recent loss stresses national harmonization?
Why is less intellectual property more desirable?

context: The stated objective of most <b4_0>intellectual property law<b4_0/> (with the exception of trademarks) is to "<a0_0>Promote progress.<a0_0/>" By exchanging limited exclusive rights for disclosure of inventions and creative works, society and the patentee/copyright owner mutually benefit, and an incentive is created for <b5_0>inventors<b5_0/> and authors to <a1_0>create and disclose their work<a1_0/>. Some commentators have noted that the objective of intellectual property legislators and those who support its implementation appears to be "absolute protection". "If some intellectual property is desirable because <b8_0>it encourages innovation<b8_0/>, they reason, more is better. The thinking is that creators will not have sufficient incentive to invent unless they are legally entitled to capture the full social value of their inventions". <b6_0>This <a2_0>absolute protection or full value<a2_0/> view<b6_0/> treats intellectual property as another type of "real" property, typically adopting its law and rhetoric. Other recent developments in intellectual property law, such as the <a3_0><b7_0>America Invents Act<b7_0/><a3_0/>, stress international harmonization. Recently there has also been much debate over the desirability of using intellectual property rights to protect cultural heritage, including intangible ones, as well as over risks of commodification derived from this possibility. The issue still remains open in legal scholarship.
